race.name: Albia Holy Cow
race.tagline: Albia Holy Cow. 60 miles of gravel through Albia.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Iowa countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Iowa event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Albia Holy Cow is a local event in Iowa‚Äîrolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Iowa countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Iowa gravel race. Worth it for Iowa/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Iowa‚Äîyes, it's good value. If you're traveling‚Äîskip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Iowa races: Trans Iowa, Spotted Horse Ultra.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Albia has limited lodging options. Book ahead.
logistics.food: Albia has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Iowa rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Monroe County Fairgrounds venue provides RV camping sites with 200-rider cap and July 5th online registration deadline showing solid planning. Albia Chamber of Commerce partnership delivers local support with promises to 'show you around downtown and their picturesque square.'

length.explanation: Trevor Irwin podiumed the 50km in 1:58:09, noting the distance was 'right in his wheelhouse' for triathletes trying gravel. Another rider set 'a personal goal to complete the race in 4:30' on the longer distance but 'came in just late of the goal.'

technicality.explanation: Course founder discovered 'a number of Class B roads' with 'river crossings' and cattle encounters through moderate terrain. Officially classified as 'rolling short steep hills or moderate, sustained climbs' - countryside exploration without technical skill demands.

elevation.explanation: Course founder describes 'a fairly hill route, but there are a lot of long descents and nice flats to help you recharge and get ready for the next Class B challenge.' 2,500 feet over 60 miles with recovery opportunities.

climate.explanation: Mid-July in Iowa delivers heat, humidity, and potential thunderstorms. Classic midwest summer conditions create endurance challenges without altitude or desert extremes affecting Monroe County fairgrounds start.

altitude.explanation: Iowa farmland through Monroe County stays near sea level. Altitude isn't a factor for Class B road challenges through cattle country and Historic Mormon Trail segments.

adventure.explanation: Course founder encountered unexpected 'acres of grass-fed cattle, beautiful views' and 'a short ride along the Historic Mormon Trail' through Monroe County exploration. Pleasant countryside discovery without wilderness edge.

prestige.explanation: Regional Iowa Gravel Series race where Trevor Irwin podiumed 'as a triathlete trying gravel' demonstrates accessible competition level. 200-rider cap and fairgrounds venue show grassroots focus over elite field attraction.

race_quality.explanation: $40 entry gets 'chip timing, marked course, pro photography and aid stations' while fairgrounds venue move shows organizational learning. Iowa Gravel Series framework covers basics competently without premium polish.

experience.explanation: Course founder called Monroe County exploration 'spectacular' after discovering unexpected cattle encounters. Albia Chamber encourages riders to 'plan to stick around after this adventure' for downtown exploration beyond racing.

community.explanation: Albia Chamber actively promotes post-race downtown exploration while Monroe County Fairgrounds RV camping creates gathering space. Iowa Gravel Series builds season-long community with $399 series pass connecting regional riders across 7 races.

field_depth.explanation: Performance spread from Trevor Irwin's competitive 1:58:09 podium to riders missing 4:30 completion goals demonstrates wide participation range. 200-rider cap shows recreational focus over competitive depth.

value.explanation: $40 grassroots entry includes 'chip timing, marked course, pro photography and aid stations' with $60 adding lunch and shirt. $399 series pass for all 7 Iowa races delivers strong economics for circuit riders.

expenses.explanation: Monroe County Fairgrounds RV camping keeps lodging affordable in rural Iowa. $40-60 entry fees and regional driving accessibility create midwest racing economics without premium destination costs.
